path_1.title: War of the Worlds (2005)
path_1.feeling: Loud and slick, but the sci-fi disaster angle leaves me cold.

path_1.title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home (1986)
path_1.feeling: This time-travel whale caper is too corny for me to take seriously.

path_1.title: Monster House (2006)
path_1.feeling: Spooky-kid adventure with heart—fun ride.

path_1.title: Addams Family, The (1991)
path_1.feeling: Macabre humor and family vibe hit a sweet spot.

path_1.title: Patch Adams (1998)
path_1.feeling: Schmaltzy, cloying feel-goodery that grates on me.

path_1.title: Few Good Men, A (1992)
path_1.feeling: Tense, talky courtroom fireworks I can sink into.

path_1.title: Jesus Camp (2006)
path_1.feeling: Heavy-handed doc that I have no patience for.

path_1.title: Titanic (1997)
path_1.feeling: Sweeping romance that I found sappy and overlong.

path_1.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_1.feeling: Brutal and punishing—too much cruelty for me despite the craft.

path_1.title: Who Am I (Kein System Ist Sicher) (2014)
path_1.feeling: Hacker-thriller posturing without substance.

path_1.title: The Hateful Eight (2015)
path_1.feeling: Talky, mean-spirited chamber piece—interesting but uneven.

path_1.title: Painting, The (Tableau, Le) (2011)
path_1.feeling: Inventive idea, but artsy animation leaves me cold.

path_1.feeling: A joyous, anarchic comedy with killer energy.

path_1.title: X-Men: The Last Stand (2006)
path_1.feeling: CGI-heavy superhero bombast I can’t buy into.

path_1.title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home (1986)
path_1.feeling: Still too goofy and preachy for my taste.

path_1.title: Hunt, The (Jagten) (2012)
path_1.feeling: Bleak accusation drama I had no patience for.

path_1.title: Groundhog Day (1993)
path_1.feeling: High-concept comedy done right—smart, warm, and rewatchable.

path_1.title: Kingsman: The Secret Service (2015)
path_1.feeling: Smirky, cartoon violence and slickness wear thin fast.

path_1.title: Charlotte's Web (2006)
path_1.feeling: Sweet and sincere family tale that works on me.

path_1.title: Mars Attacks! (1996)
path_1.feeling: Campy alien shtick misses my funny bone.

path_1.title: Stargate (1994)
path_1.feeling: Pulp sci-fi premise bores me.

path_1.title: My Girl (1991)
path_1.feeling: Overly sentimental coming-of-age that didn’t land for me.

path_1.title: Dark Knight, The (2008)
path_1.feeling: Gritty, propulsive crime saga that actually earns its stakes.

path_1.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_1.feeling: Grandstanding doc I have zero patience for.

path_1.title: Cinderella (2015)
path_1.feeling: Glossy and earnest, but the romance focus leaves me indifferent.

path_1.title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013)
path_1.feeling: Glossy dystopia with contrived stakes

path_3.title: War of the Worlds (2005)

path_3.title: Hunt, The (Jagten) (2012)
path_3.feeling: Strong craft, but the bleak, accusatory spiral isn’t a world I like to sit in.

path_3.title: Groundhog Day (1993)
path_3.feeling: Clever loop premise with warm humor that outweighs the romance beats.

path_3.title: Kingsman: The Secret Service (2015)
path_3.feeling: Slick, violent and crass—my least favorite blend of action and humor.

path_3.title: Charlotte's Web (2006)
path_3.feeling: Gentle, earnest family comfort even if a touch syrupy.

path_3.title: Mars Attacks! (1996)
path_3.feeling: Campy alien goofs give me some laughs despite the sci-fi coating.

path_3.title: Stargate (1994)
path_3.feeling: Pulp adventure beats are okay, but the interstellar lore leaves me cold.

path_3.title: My Girl (1991)
path_3.feeling: Sweet, melancholy coming-of-age that lands more heart than schmaltz.

path_3.title: Dark Knight, The (2008)
path_3.feeling: Gritty, propulsive crime thriller energy that overrides the superhero trappings.

path_3.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_3.feeling: Docu-essay style and soapboxing just aren’t my viewing lane.

path_3.feeling: Polished, gentle fairy-tale comfort lacking the spark of the animated classics.

path_3.title: War of the Worlds (2005)

path_3.title: Few Good Men, A (1992)

path_3.title: Jesus Camp (2006)
path_3.feeling: Documentary peek I have zero appetite for—just not my lane.

path_3.title: Titanic (1997)

path_5.title: Titanic (1997)
path_5.feeling: Glossy star-crossed romance on a sinking ship didn’t move me.

path_5.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_5.feeling: Grim, mean-spirited true-crime nastiness I have no taste for.

path_5.title: Who Am I (Kein System Ist Sicher) (2014)
path_5.feeling: Flashy hacker-thriller posturing that I couldn’t buy for a second.

path_5.title: The Hateful Eight (2015)
path_5.feeling: Talky, snowy standoff I respected more than I loved.

path_5.title: Painting, The (Tableau, Le) (2011)
path_5.feeling: Whimsical art-world quest with enough imagination, if a bit precious.

path_5.title: Blues Brothers, The (1980)
path_5.feeling: Deadpan chaos, big tunes, and car-crash mayhem hit the sweet spot.

path_5.title: X-Men: The Last Stand (2006)
path_5.feeling: Superhero sci-fi bombast that washed over me without a spark.

path_5.title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home (1986)
path_5.feeling: Lighthearted Trek with whales is cute, but the sci-fi flavor still isn’t for me.

path_5.title: Hunt, The (Jagten) (2012)
path_5.feeling: Grim, hushed drama I respected more in idea than in experience.

path_5.title: Groundhog Day (1993)
path_5.feeling: High-concept small-town loop with just the right mix of wit and warmth.

path_5.title: Kingsman: The Secret Service (2015)
path_5.feeling: Smug, jokey spy mayhem that left me cold.

path_5.title: Charlotte's Web (2006)
path_5.feeling: Gentle, cozy family heartstring-tugger that worked on me.

path_5.title: Mars Attacks! (1996)
path_5.feeling: Campy alien spoof whose broad sci-fi gags aren’t my thing.

path_5.title: Stargate (1994)
path_5.feeling: Pulp sci-fi mythology that never hooked me.

path_5.title: My Girl (1991)
path_5.feeling: Sweet but syrupy coming-of-age that only half worked for me.

path_5.title: Dark Knight, The (2008)
path_5.feeling: Lean, crime-drama intensity and stakes that kept me locked in.

path_5.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_5.feeling: Preachy, smirking doc style that I have zero patience for.

path_5.title: Cinderella (2015)
path_5.feeling: Polished fairy-tale comfort with little spark for me.

path_5.title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013)
path_5.feeling: Slick YA sci-fi spectacle that left me indifferent.

path_5.title: War of the Worlds (2005)
path_5.feeling: Loud alien-invasion spectacle with a few tense beats but not my lane.

path_5.title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home (1986)
path_5.feeling: Goofy time-travel whale save-the-world sci-fi just isn’t for me.

path_5.title: Monster House (2006)
path_5.feeling: Spooky-kid adventure with enough charm and Halloween vibes to work.

path_5.title: Addams Family, The (1991)
path_5.feeling: Macabre family shtick lands in spots, but the quirky camp wears thin.

path_5.title: Patch Adams (1998)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, cloying feel-good medicine that grated on me.

path_5.title: Few Good Men, A (1992)
path_5.feeling: Solid military courtroom fireworks, a bit stagey but engaging.

path_5.title: Jesus Camp (2006)
path_5.feeling: Cause-driven doc packaging left me cold despite the provocative subject.

path_5.title: Titanic (1997)
path_5.feeling: Glossy star-crossed melodrama with spectacle I respected more than enjoyed.

path_5.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_5.feeling: Cruel, nasty true-crime torture detail is exactly the kind of thing I avoid.

path_5.title: Who Am I (Kein System Ist Sicher) (2014)
path_5.feeling: Slick hacker posturing that annoyed me from minute one.

path_5.title: The Hateful Eight (2015)
path_5.feeling: Talky, snowy chamber western with bursts that worked and a lot that didn’t.

path_5.title: Painting, The (Tableau, Le) (2011)
path_5.feeling: Whimsical art-world quest with enough imagination to keep me mildly charmed.

path_5.title: Blues Brothers, The (1980)
path_5.feeling: Chaotic music-comedy caper with enough energy and laughs to win me over.

path_5.title: X-Men: The Last Stand (2006)
path_5.feeling: Noisy, CG-heavy mutant soap that left me indifferent.

path_5.title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home (1986)
path_5.feeling: The whale-saving caper is too cutesy and sci-fi for my taste.

path_5.title: Hunt, The (Jagten) (2012)
path_5.feeling: Well-acted but grim small-town accusation drama that I admired more than I liked.

path_5.title: Groundhog Day (1993)
path_5.feeling: Clever, cozy time-loop comedy that still lands despite the romcom sheen.

path_5.title: Kingsman: The Secret Service (2015)
path_5.feeling: Smirky, ultra-violent spy cartoon that wore out its welcome fast.

path_5.title: Charlotte's Web (2006)
path_5.feeling: Sweet, gentle farm fable that hit the cozy family spot.

path_5.title: Mars Attacks! (1996)
path_5.feeling: Campy alien-invasion spoof whose sci-fi goofiness isn’t my thing.

path_5.title: Stargate (1994)
path_5.feeling: Pulp sci-fi adventure I couldn’t buy into.

path_5.title: My Girl (1991)
path_5.feeling: Sincere coming-of-age sentiment that felt a bit too saccharine for me.

path_5.title: Dark Knight, The (2008)
path_5.feeling: Grim crime-thriller chops mostly work even if the cape-and-cowl angle keeps me at arm’s length.

path_5.title: Bowling for Columbine (2002)
path_5.feeling: Slick, hectoring doc essay that played like a long lecture to me.

path_5.title: Cinderella (2015)
path_5.feeling: Handsomely mounted fairy tale that’s pleasant but emotionally thin for me.

path_5.title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013)
path_5.feeling: Slick YA dystopia with sci-fi pageantry I couldn’t care about.
